awd_titl_txt: Mind, Brain and Education in STEM Learning: Research, Policy and Practice Collaboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to New York University will provide support for a workshop on Mind, Brain, and Education scheduled to be held in New York City in January 2020. It will bring researchers from multiple fields (e.g., education research, cognitive science, neuroscience) together with education practitioners (e.g., teachers, district leaders, parents) to share ideas about brain research and STEM learning in both formal and informal contexts. It will be an opportunity for researchers to share the results of their cutting-edge work on such topics as numerical processing and STEM problem solving with educators and, in turn, for educators to have direct input to researchers about issues concerning the translation to practice. It will also provide educators with the opportunity to help drive basic and applied research agendas. The goal of the workshop is to develop new models for sustained collaborations among researchers, educators, parents, and policy influencers. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which supports fundamental research that advances the research literature on STEM learning.

The workshop will explore innovative models of interaction between researchers and educators in the nascent field of Mind, Brain, and Education, centering on collaboratories - table discussions on specific topics led by a range of top experts so as to foster dialogue - as well as networking sessions, rapid-fire talks, keynote addresses, and a session devoted to discovering new models for sustained interaction of the gathered communities. The specific topics will may include cognitive neuroscientific findings related to inducing durable memories in STEM, cognitive findings about the geometric intuitions that underlie formal learning in mathematics, establishing researcher-practitioner partnerships in STEM education, teaching science at the secondary school level, supporting museum-university collaborations, and best practices in public outreach.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a transformative workshop on Mind, Brain, and Education (MBE) in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Learning, held on January 15, 2024, in New York City. The event, led by Drs. Vanessa Rodriguez and Ido Davidesco, successfully gathered approximately 60 participants, including researchers from diverse fields such as education, cognitive science, and neuroscience, along with education practitioners, including teachers, district leaders, and parents. The overarching goal was to foster collaboration and dialogue between researchers and educators to enhance STEM learning through insights from neuroscience.

Intellectual Merit 

One of the key intellectual outcomes of this project was the facilitation of interdisciplinary collaboration. Traditionally, there has been a disconnect between neuroscience research and educational practice. This workshop served as a vital platform for bridging that gap. Participants engaged in meaningful discussions about how the latest research findings in cognitive science could inform effective teaching strategies in STEM education. Through keynote presentations and design thinking tables, attendees explored various topics, including play-based STEM learning, brain development, and social-emotional awareness in education.

The design thinking tables, in particular, enabled participants to brainstorm innovative solutions to pressing challenges in STEM education. By encouraging active participation and input from both researchers and educators, the workshop fostered a shared understanding of the translational value of neuroscience in real-world classroom settings. The success of this approach was reflected in the overwhelmingly positive feedback from participants, with 80% rating the workshop as "excellent." Many noted that the workshop expanded their perspectives on STEM learning, highlighting the importance of collaborative dialogue in shaping educational practices.

Broader Impacts

The workshop emphasized promoting equity in STEM education, aligning with the values celebrated on Martin Luther King Jr. Day. The inclusion of a panel discussion focused on building equity through MBE principles underscored the importance of ensuring that all students, particularly those from underrepresented backgrounds, have access to high-quality STEM learning experiences. This focus on equity is crucial in reshaping educational environments, as it encourages educators to develop inclusive teaching strategies that engage and support diverse student populations.

The professional development opportunities provided by the workshop were significant. Educators left feeling empowered to apply new ideas and methodologies in their classrooms. The collaborative nature of the event fostered a sense of community among participants, enabling them to share best practices and learn from one another. This shared experience is likely to have lasting effects, as educators integrate what they learned into their teaching.

Another important outcome of the workshop was the establishment of frameworks for sustained collaboration among participants. By encouraging ongoing partnerships between researchers, educators, parents, and policy influencers, the workshop set the groundwork for future research initiatives and collaborative projects focused on enhancing STEM education. The commitment to continuous engagement will ensure that the insights gained during the workshop can translate into lasting changes in educational practices.

Conclusion

In summary, the workshop on Mind, Brain, and Education in STEM Learning produced significant outcomes that addressed both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project. By fostering interdisciplinary collaboration, promoting equity, enhancing professional development, and laying the groundwork for future partnerships, the workshop has positioned itself as a catalyst for positive change in STEM education. As participants implement the ideas and strategies gained from this event, we can expect to see meaningful improvements in teaching practices and student learning experiences, ultimately contributing to a more informed and inclusive STEM educational landscape. Bridging the research-practice gap through collaborative interactions between researchers and educators has the potential for substantial societal impact, ensuring that educational practices are grounded in solid scientific research while also being responsive to the needs of diverse learners.
